cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

row.cell:
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
Le réseau de cable télégraphiques sous-marins de cette compagnie
constitue le moyen de communication le plus
direct et le plus rapide d'Egypte pour l'Europe, l'Amérique
du Nord et du Sud, L,Afrique orientale, méridionale
et occidentale, les Indes, l'Australie, la Nouvelle-Zélande, la
Chine et le Japon.
Pour assurer une transmission rapide, les télégrammes
doivent porter l'indication Viâ Eastern.
Voir le temps moyen de transmission le plus récent jusqu'à
Londres au belletin journalier publié dans ce journal.
STATIONS EN EGYPTE. Alexandrie, le Caire, Suez,
Port-Tewfik, Port-Said, Suakin. Bureau principal à Londres.

div.head: ADMIRAL TOGO. SAILS FOR UNKNOWN DESTINATION.

div.p: Adrdiral Togo bas lett kure for an unknown destination, going probably towards the Soutli.
(llavas.)
Admiral Togo has sailed, his destination * being unknown.
(Reuter.)
The British steniner "Eartry" has been released, the capture having been a mistake.
(Reuter.)
Work is being resumed more and more in the Rubir basin.

div.head: THE BRINDISI MAIL
div.p: will be distributed at the G.P.O., Alexandrin, at 7.45 a,m. to morrow.

div.head: THE WHITE STAR
div.p: liner "Romanio" arrived at Alexandria this morning from Boston and Naples with about 150 tourists on board for Cairo.

div.head: ALHAMBRA THEATRE. --
div.p: A gala performance is announced for Friday next in honor of the artistic director of the ballet troupe, Sig. Euzo Longhi.

div.head: Suez Canal.
div.p: On the 9th and 10th inst. 25 vessels passed through the Canal, 20 of which were British, 1 Dutch, 1 German, 1 Austrian, 2 French. The receipts for the two days were frs, 703,792.82, making the total from 1st inst. frs. 3,761,733.51.

div.head: ORIENTAL CONGRESS. --
div.p: The Egyptian Government has decided to take part in the Congress of Orientalists which will be held at Algiers during the present year, and Sultan Effendi Muhamed, Abdul Aziz Jaoniche, and Sheikh Hamed wil represent Eypt at the Congress.

div.head: EGYPT AT ST. LOUIS.---
div.p: Mr. John Wanamaker, of Philadelphia, has purchased half of the Egyptian authropological exhibit at the World's Fair, St. Louis, which included an ancient sarcophagus and a mummy (200 B.C.), for the Philadelphia diusuun. The price paid for the exhibits aggregated about $70,000.

div.head: CAKE WALK COMPETITION. -
div.p: One of the chief incidents of the forthcoming Cairo 'Tradesmen's Ball is to be the grand cake walk competitiou. It is expected that this competition will actract a number of entries. A valuable prize is to be presented to the most perfect "cake walker."

div.head: CHARITY LOTTERY.
div.p: Mime de la Boulimiere has received a beautiful Sèvres vase from the President of the French Republic for the Lottery which she has organised in aid of the home for the aged, the orphanages, and the dispensaries in Old Cairo. The lottery is to be drawn at the French Agency to-day.

div.head: AN IMPORTANT DISCOVERY.
div.p: M. Berthelot, secretary of the Louvre Museum, believes that he has discovered the secret of the ageut usou un emuaming in ancient Egypt. Aiter & labo riuus uxalmination of the sarcophage of the fitch and sixtu dynasties, which dates back & Iar as 3500 B.O., M. Berthelut Las come tu thu decislou that the oil employed Was numpay castor oil, such as is still used in tyypt, whicu has uudergone some vXlua Lou, but rutanud during the long perlud its preservative qualities.

div.head: OUR VISITORS.
div.p: Every day our newspapers give a list of the illustrous guests who are attracted to Egypt by the delightful climate. Several of these devole part of their leisure to the study of French, English, German, Arabie, etc., at the Berlitz schools, at Alexandria, aud especially at Cairo, where there is very much stir. The renown of the system is universal, and besides there is the advantage of the transier tickets, which allow the tourist to continue in Europe or America the lessons begun in Cairo or Alexandria.

div.head: A GUIDE TO EGYPT.
div.p: To the capable hands of Dr. Wallis Budgy, of the British Museum, has been entrusted the task of writing Cook's Handbook of Egypt and the Sudan" (Thoma Cook aud Son), and he has succeeded in making a subject, interesting enough in itself, still mune interesting by the Wealth of knowledge brought to bear on it. Profusely illustrateu with maps and sketches, the work enables even the stay-at-home traveller to almost believe himself in the land of the Pharaohs, while to those fortunate enough to Visit the East it is absolutely indispensable.

div.head: The BRISTOL HOTEL.--
div.p: Mr. Bauer, the manager of the Briswi Holei, Cairo, bas taken over tuu luase of this popular resurt of visitors t the Capital direct from the proprietors of the builuuy. Mr. Bauer, who has already greaty improved this hotel, mtulids to rearrange tue whule builuing and rejuruish it anew, 80 that il will be in every respect one of the most upw-date establishments of tue kind in the Capital. This news will be received with great pleasury by the onents of the Bristol Hotel, wuch bas been so excellently managed for some time past by Mr. Bauer.

div.head: THE PHILOPTOCHOS. --
div.p: Tuat excellent Greek benevolent society, the Poiloptuchos of Alexaridris, is giving its annual grand "Vegione" at thu Zizinia Theatre next Saturday evening under the patronage of the collowing ladies ut the committee : Mesdames A. Pangulos (president p. i.), C. Sitadmo vice-presiueut), Virginie Emm. Benachi (treasurer), 0. M. Salvago, A. C. Zervudaclit, M. Sinaudino, G. C. Zervudachi, Const. Chyremni, N. Tsamis, F. Franghiadi, c. Rodocanachi, C. Mavroskoufi, JA. Anastasiadi, A. Valassopoulo, 4. Prazzica, J. Sevastopoulo, E. O. Zervudachi, J. Lagonico, G. Jacovidi, and A. Assimacopoulo.

div.head: OFFICIAL SALARIES.-
div.p: The question of the proportions that should prevait between official salaries and the recent abnormal rise in price of all the necessities of life in Egypt is to be seriously considered by the Government, which has approved of the institution of a committee charged with the study of the situation with a view to improvement. This committee, which will be presided over by Mr. Macbell, the Advisur to the Minietry of the Interior, will consist of the Director-General of the Accounts Department to the Ministry of Finance, the Director-General of Customs, and the Direotor. General of the Survey Department,

div.head: CAIRO AGRICULTURAL SHOW.
LIST OF PRIZE WINNERS.
div.p: Owing to the bad cotton season of 1904, 1 fewer 1st prizes have been given this year than in recent exbibitions, but the average of the exhibits is very fair notwithstanding, and there are some interesting features which deserve special notice. The Daira Sanieh have obtained two special 1st prizes, one for Ashmouni cotton grown as far south as Erment, ! and one for excellent Afifi grown at the same place. The better known varieties of cotton, Jannovich, Afifi, Ashmouni, Alume, are well represented, and of the new and less known varieties there is an excellent show of Nubari and a beautiful example of Charara from Me.. noufieh, with excellent samples of Voltos and Kerki.
The grain exhibits are decidedly good, the | Princesses Nimet and Anineh Hanem, Omar

Bey Sultan, Priuce Omar Pasha Toussoun, Riaz Pasha, Boghios Pasha Nubar, and A. Zeid Bey Tautawi being prominent among the prize winners. The Kom Ombo Company's exbibit deserves special mention, as it includes wheat harvested on the 4th inst, and barley harvested on the 15th January, 1905 L

Some interesting pot experiments with various fertilisers are well worth notice, while among the animals and poultry exhibited, Prince Omar l'æ ha Toussuun's specimens are particularly five. The mats and straw work exhibited are very prettily designed and look durable. The following are the prize-winners for cereals :Class.
64. Red Saidi Wheat.-1. Omar Bey Sul-! tan ; 2. M. Bey Mahfaz ; 3. A. Zeid Bey Tan tawi ; 4. Prince Omar Toussoun.
65. White Wheat from Upper Egypt.11. Ali Awad ; 2. A. Zeid Bey Tantawi.
67. White Egyptian Wheat : a) grown in Gharbieh Moudirieh. 1. Abdu Eff. Girgis.
b) In Menoufich. No award.
c) In Charkieh.--1. Princesses Amineh and Nimat lancm ; 2. Teftish Katr Hammam.
d) In Behera. 3. Riaz Pasha.
69. Any Variety of Foreign White Wheat grown in Egypt. -1, Princesses Amineh And Nimet Hanein ; 2. Mah. Bey El Ghonomy. ]
70. Native Barley.--1. Princesses Aminehi and Nimat Hanem ; 2. Riaz Pa-ba.
72. Beheri Beans. -- 1. and 2. Princesses Amineh and Nimat Hanem ; 3. Riaz Pasha.
73. Saidi Beans.-1. A. Said Bey Radi; 2. Omar Bey Sultan.
74 Native Maize.-1. Sheikh Abd el Baki Abdullah, Omar Bey Sultan, and the Princesses Amineh and Nimet Hunem. (Seven 2ud, six 3rd, and two 4th prizes were awarded).
75 Foreign Maize grown in Egypt.--1. A. Zeid Bey Tantuwi and Prince Omar Toussoun; 2. Omar Bey Sultan.
76 Millet.-1. A. Zeid Bey Tantawi ; 2. Omar Bey Sultan.
77 Saltani Rice.- 1. Moh. Boy Tewfik Shaheb; 2. A. Eft Girgis.
78 Sabaini Rice.-1. Abd el Baki Haroun; 2. Seif el Nasr Buy Tantawi and Ibr. Sidi Abmed.
79 Any other variety of Rice.-1. Mitwalli el Kloh ; 2. Wali Bey Ali.
[In all the above classes first prize winners obtained a silver gilt, the second a silver, and other prize-wippers a bronze medal.]
81 Saidi Lontils.--1. Omar Bey Sultan.
82 Earth Nuts.-- 1. Abd el Mohamed Bey Moussa ; 2. Kassim Bey Mourad.
83 Linseed.-- 1. Moh. el Tahawi, 2. Seif el Nasr Bey Tantawi.
84 White Sesame.-1. Kassim Bey Monrad.
85 Brown Sesame.--1. Kassim Bey Mourad; | 2. Prince Omar Pasha Toussoun.
(In these classes first prize winners obtained | a silver, others a bronze medal.]
86 Fenugreek. - Silver Medal and 1st. Princesses Amineh and Nimat Hassan ; 2. Omar Bey Sultan. | 87 Baali Bersim Seed. -Equal 1st: Princesses Amineh and Nimat Hassan and Boghos Pasha Nabar.
88 Miscawi Bersim Seed.-Equal Ist : Princesses Amineh and Nimet Hanem and Rinz Pasba.
89 Colza. -Omar Bey Sultan. Yeal. 2. Riaz Pasba and Boghos Pasha Nubar. Gelban. -Teftish Arnent. Rayana.--Prince Omar Pasha Toussoun.
Behøri Beans.--2. 8. Bey Ahmed Abaga. Special Silver Gilt Medal to Wadi Kom Ombo.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive, after attending KourbanBeyram prayers yesterday morning at Koubbeh Mosque, proceeded to Abdeen Palace to hold the Kourban-Beyram reception, which was nutnerously attended.
On Monday the Khedive gave audience to Sheikh Mohamed Abdou, Grand Moufti of B:ypt, who gave a description to his Highness of his recent trip to the Sudan.

div.head: THE LATE E. J. MANUK.
div.p: The funeral of the late Mr. E. J. Manuk, whose sudden death on Sunday came as a shock to the many friends he possessed in Cairo, took place on Monday afternoon, amidst a large
concourse of people. The chief mourner was | the deceased's brother, Mr. E C. Manuk, of

Alexandria, and the mortal remains of the | deceased were followed to their last resting J place by everyone distinguished in the world of finance and of commerce, of which Mr. Mamuk was a prominent member. There was an iminense quantity of wreaths. The burial service was held at St. Joseph's Church,
Ismailia, and the interment took place in 1 & temporary vault in the Latin cemetery. A number of shops on the line of ronte of the fa neral were closed as a sign of respeot for the deceased.

div.head: THE ROYAL VISIT. A TRIP TO KARNAK.

div.p: The Duke and Duchess of Connaught are expected to reach Luxor tomorrow. They will remain at Luxor till Thursday. Instructions had been issued by the Ministry of the Interior to the Moudir to proceed to Luxor in order I to be in attendance on the Doke during his stay there. The Moudir, accompanied by the Police Commandant, is leaving at noon for Luxor. I learn that the railway authorities have arranged to send a special train from Cairo to Luxor on Wednesday for the purpose of conveying the Royal party back to Cairo.

The Duke and Duchess of Connaught spent last night at Arment and arrived here this morning at 10 o'clock. All the consular agents and the moudirieh officials were waiting at the lauding-stage to welcome the Royal visitors. The two Princesses landed first and rode to ] Karnak, one og horseback and the other on a donkey. The Duchess and inite followed later, and afterwards the Duke, with General Sir J. Maxwell. All went on donkeys. The party returned about noon, and the Duke and Duchess went on board their yacht after a short walk on the quay, while the Princesses went on a visit to the town.

The Duke and Duchess of Connaught changed their landing-stage from the Anglo-American Company's platform to a landing-stage at Karnak, which the Government had already prepared for them, and which, I suppose, faci. litated their visit to the ruins. About 3 p.m. they went to visit the Tombs of the Kings, where they took tea.

div.head: THE EX-EMPRESS EUGENIE.
div.p: The ex-Empress Eugenie and suite arrived here this afternoon about 4 o'clock from Cairo in a dababieh. The distinguished lady landed at about five and paid a short visit to Luxor Temple, afterwardsproceeding to the Luxor Hotel, where she took tea and perused the latest telegrams.

div.head: PRINCE OF SWEDEN'S VISIT.
div.p: H. R. H. Prince Gustavus Adolphus of Sweden and Norway is paying a visit to Luxor incognito on a private dababieh. Yesterday he dined at the Luxor Hotel, and to-day he has been visiting some antiquity shops and merchants. Two plain-clothes policemen sre keeping watch over him.

div.head: LORD CROMER'S TRIP.
div.p: Lord and Lady Cromer, accompanied by Lady Beatrice Thynne, arrived here this morning on their stram dahabieh. The distinguished party stopped here for about two hours, daring which time Lady Cromer visited Luxor Temple. They afterwards proceeded to Assouan.

div.head: SUPREME CONSULAR COURT.
div.p: Mr. Pigott, the acting Chief Justice of His Majesty's Supreme Consular Court for the Dominions of the Sublime Ottoman Porte, will arrive here on Saturday next from Constantinople and will proceed direct to Cairo.
There are no cases down for hearing at Alexandria.

div.head: EXCAVATIONS ON THE CANAL
div.p: At the last meeting of the Academy of Inscriptions and Belles lettres of Paris it was announced that the board of the Suez Canal Company had decided to commence archæological excavations in the region traversed by the Saez Canal. The work will be enfanted to M. Clédat, of the Cairo Archäological Institnte, and the excavations will begin at Tel el-Herr.

div.head: THE FITZNER QUARTETTE.
div.p: The following is the programme of the second concert to be given at the New Khedivial Hotel, Alexandria, on Friday, 17th inst., by the Fitzner Quartette - 1. GLAZOUNOW : Quatuor Ré-majeur (Op. 70)
a) Andante Allegro b) Allegretto o) Adagio
d) Allegro. 2. DVORAK: Lento (Dumky)
CHERUBINI: Scherzo. 3. BEETHOVEN : Quatuor Mi mineur (Op.59
No. 2) a) Allegro b) Molto Adagio o). Allegretto
d) Finale presto. Tickets (P.T. 40 each, or P.T. 100 for family of 3) may be had at Hack's music stores, Cherif Pasha Street.
TYROL

Weissenstein Castle 3410 . ft. First-class private hotel near Windisch-Matrei; Station, Liens (reached from Venice or Trieste). Bracing air. Good Mountaineering centre. Tennis Pishing. Best June, September. Apply Proprietan

The Messageries Maritimes mil steamer "Australien," having General Swessel, Mme. Stoessel, and 498 officers and men of the Port Arthur garrison on board, artived at Saen at 9 o'cloek this morning, en rute for Port Said, where they will embark on board the Roskian steamer "Saint Nicolas" for Odessa. .
The "Australien" entered the Canal at 1.30 this afternoon.
The Messageries steamer "Australien," with General and Mme. Stoensel and the officers and men accompanying him, is nowin the Canal and is due at Port Said early to-morrow morning.
The "Saint Nicolas" reached bere from Odessa yesterday, and is now awaiting their arrival
E: General Stoessel transhipped from the. 8.8. "Anstralien" to the 8.8. "St. Nicolas" at 9.30 a.m. to day. The latter steamer leaves for Theodosia at 3 o'dlock this afternoon.

div.head: ANOTHER TURBINE STEAMER.
div.p: Another new tarbine steamer, the "Lanka” (Capt. Wilson), arrived at Port Said this morning bound for Colombo. She was built by Messrs. Denny and Co., of Glasgow, for the British India Steam Navigation Company. Her speed from Glasgow, which she left on the 4th inst., has averaged 147 knots, but she is capable of 19. She has accommodation for 48 first-class passengers, and will probably run between Calentta and Rangoon.

div.head: THE “C. O. D.” SYSTEM.
div.p: We understand that the suggestions contained in our leading article of Thursday last bave been received with a considerable amount of favor by the authorities, and that steps will be taken to introduce the cash-on-delivery system of the postal service between Egypt and the Sudan.
We have good reason to believe, too, that the opposition to the establishment of the system between Egypt and England is likely to be overcome.

div.head: SMUGGLING AT ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: The Coastguards at Alexandria have been very busy the last few days in seizing contraband goods in the shape of firearms, hashish, ammunition, powder, etc.
On Sunday morning, 143 kilos of hashishi was seized near the landing-stage inside the enclosure of the Ports and Lighthouses Ad. ministration.

Yesterday, on searching the Italian 8.8. "Nina," the Coastguards found two large portmanteaux, containing 70 kilos of hashish, | and also the following treasure trove : 101 breech-loading rifles of all kinds, including Martini-Henry, Chassepot, and Gras, 11 revolvers, some of them exquisitely mounted with ivory handles, 1,490 ball (rifle) cartridges, 1,474 ball (revolver) cartridges, 250,000 per cussion caps for Arab sporting guns, 19 tins of sporting powder, and 4,900 choice Havana cigars.
The night previous to this haul the smugglers had kept the Coastguards baay in the harbour and there were some exciting chases.

It is surmised that the rifles and ammunition were intended for the Tripoli coast, where the vessel would land them on her return voyage. The arms are too unwieldly. to be landed at Alexandria without detection. This is the largest haul of valuable contraband that has been made at Alexandria this year.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Ellerman 8.8. "Sardinia," now on the berth for Liverpool, will sail for that port on Sanday.

div.p: The reason at Hietotas ir to prove e record one, the hotele pensions are early all fall, and the work in consequence presents quite a Thoongo in the management of the way has already down evidenes that de confort and convenience of

p ages and to be the ded to, but mucha velito to be done this two termini are still surrounded with n aid loafers. The authorities would be walle d if they retained a portion of the phutuna separated off for first and second on egors, especially as no waiting rooms to provided. Further, there is a great want of a te lounge wooden costs for people who arrivo * to mi nutes before the arrival of the train to Hellows apon. The lighting of the stations magtit be greatly improved. Seeing that this towns of Heloman has now an excellent electrio supty, why should its station remain asboot in darkness, the sole supply of light at present consisting of some ancient oil lampe 1

div.head: WANTED_A BANK -
div.p: Whilst mentioning, local improvements I should like to point out the wait of enterprise on the part of the various big Helouan alrehdy oontains son t thousand inhabitants, each year & langely intruning number of visitors, and yet not one of the Byptian banks has a branch bare The establishment of one would prove most wel. come.

div.head: POST OFFICE COMPLAINTS.
div.p: Again, a considerable datoe of annogunos to residents and visitors are the short hours that the post office is open auch day, it seine nothing short of a publio scandal that it shoäld be closed at all during the day. At present one is debarred from even purchasing a postage stamp during at least five hours of the ordinary working day.

div.head: THE RACES.
div.p: The races instituted by the Holocan Sporting Club, last year, have 'proved great Success this season, the attendance at anch of the first two meetings has been all that dould be desired, and there is every prospect of another good day at the meeting to be held next Friday.

div.head: GOLFING..
div.p: The Helouan Golf Club is again proving great attraction to visitors, the weekly com, petitions being keonly contested. The Nango. vich Company, by whom the links are maintrained, have generously doubled the start this season, and in consequence the links, hava been greatly improved and have never beda in better order.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: H.B.M.': Consal-General at Alsandha and Mrs. Gould gave a largely attended "At Home" at the British Consulate last night. The new codisalar residente adapta itaoli admirtbly to social fandtions, and the many groots of Mr. and Mrs. Gould, including a number of forsiga Consuls and a representative gathering of the British colony, enjoyed a most pleacaat evening Mr. and Mrs. Gould will be at home and to-morrow evening.

Eighty passengers landed yesterday after noon at Port Said from the P. and 0. 8.8. "China" (Capt. G. K. Wright, RNR). Among the most distinguished were Mr. H. W. and Lady Hope, Sir Gerald Fitagozald, Sir A Coote, Barts, and Lady Coote, Sir R. H. Brown, and Mrs. Ivor Guest.
Mr. N. Kalomiris, F.R.O.8., and Mn. Kalomiris arrived at Alexandria from London by the 8.8. "Senegal."

div.head: EXPORT MANIFESTS.
div.p: For LONDON, by the 8.8. Sigyn, sailed op the 6th Febrary
